comments:
It seems to load the library fine, and mozilla itself runs fine as well, but 
when using the browser widget I get the error below. Even worse is that 
Eclipse doesn't start up if a view in the default perspective is causing this 
error; it seems like it is never caught and causes the whole application not 
to start up.. 
 
 
org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles [Unknown mozilla path] 
        at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:2717) 
        at org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser.<init>(Browser.java:128)

It failed because the location of the Mozilla distribution was not found. I 
have some questions for you below.

Some general info first: the SWT FAQ contains info regarding this kind of 
issue:

- What do I need to run the SWT Browser inside Eclipse on Linux GTK or Linux 
Motif?
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt-
home/faq.html#browserlinux

- What do I need to run the SWT Browser in a standalone application on Linux 
GTK or Linux Motif?
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt-
home/faq.html#browserlinuxrcp

Now let's see.

1. Which Linux distribution are you using?
2. Do you start Eclipse through the eclipse launcher or through the java 
command line?
3. How and where did you install Mozilla 1.6?

If your Mozilla 1.6 is installed in /usr/lib/mozilla-1.6, you can try the 
following:
- open a terminal
- setenv MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME /usr/lib/mozilla-1.6  (for cshell users)
- eclipse

You should go further. Please let us know about 1. 2. and 3. to help us 
understand what is happening.

MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME did the trick. I've just never had to-do that step before. 
 
The problem occured when installing SuSE 9.1. It worked fine with both RedHat 
9 and SuSe 9.0 without setting any additional parameters. But I probably 
installed an RPM of Mozilla which set that up, and I couldn't use the SuSE 9.1 
RPM because the version number was too high (they ship with Mozilla 1.7 which 
SWT also didn't like)....

RH9 and Suse9 both come with a supported version of Mozilla (1.4GTK2). In 
addition, these 2 platforms set a config file /etc/gre.conf that specify the 
location of Mozilla. This file is found by the eclipse launcher to 
automatically set MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME and LD_LIBRARY_PATH correctly. So that's 
why it was working before. When this file is not there - or to override it - 
MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME must be set.

For Mozilla 1.7, you can monitor bug 61384 for updates.

Can you confirm Suse 9.1 comes with Mozilla 1.7? Thanks!
